title: 109_hr212
content: The Act is titled the "Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals Judgeship and Reorganization Act of 2005." It defines terms like "former ninth circuit," "new ninth circuit," and "twelfth circuit." The Act also addresses the number and composition of circuits. SEC. 3 amends Section 41 of title 28, United States Code, by changing the number and composition of circuits. The ninth circuit is redefined to include Arizona, California, and Nevada, while the twelfth circuit is established to include Alaska, Guam, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Northern Mariana Islands, Oregon, and Washington. SEC. 4 addresses judgeships. The President will appoint additional circuit judges for the former ninth circuit in Arizona, California, or Nevada, as well as for the new ninth circuit. These appointments require Senate approval and must not occur before January 21, 2006. Additionally, temporary judgeships will be filled in the former ninth circuit to address vacancies. The first 2 vacancies on the new ninth circuit occurring 10 years after judges are confirmed to fill temporary judgeships created by this subsection will not be filled. This section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5 amends the table in title 28, United States Code, by changing the number of circuit judges for the ninth and twelfth circuits. SEC. 6 updates the locations of circuit courts for the ninth and twelfth circuits. SEC. 7 of the Act assigns circuit judges from the former ninth circuit to either the new ninth circuit or the twelfth circuit based on their official duty station. SEC. 8 allows senior judges to elect their assignment. Senior circuit judges from the former ninth circuit can choose to be assigned to the new ninth circuit or the twelfth circuit. Their seniority will be based on their commission date as a judge of the former ninth circuit. This election process applies to cases as well. The Act specifies procedures for cases pending in the former ninth circuit before the effective date of the Act. If a matter has been submitted for decision, proceedings will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. If not submitted, the appeal or proceeding will be transferred to the appropriate court as if the Act had been in effect, with further proceedings conducted similarly. The Act specifies procedures for cases pending in the former ninth circuit before the effective date of the Act. A petition for rehearing or rehearing en banc in a matter decided before the Act's effective date will be treated as if the Act had not been enacted. If rehearing en banc is granted, the matter will be reheard by a court as if the Act had not been enacted. SEC. 11 allows for temporary assignment of circuit judges between the Ninth and Twelfth Circuits, upon request by the chief judges. SEC. 12 pertains to temporary assignment of district judges between circuits. Section 292 of title 28, United States Code, allows for temporary assignment of district judges between the Ninth and Twelfth Circuits in the public interest. The chief judge of each circuit can designate and assign judges to sit on the Court of Appeals or hold district court in the other circuit when necessary. The chief judge of the Twelfth Circuit can temporarily assign judges to the Ninth Circuit when needed, in accordance with the rules of the court of appeals. SEC. 13. ADMINISTRATIVE COORDINATION. Two contiguous circuits may jointly carry out administrative functions as determined by their judicial councils. SEC. 14. ADMINISTRATION. The ninth circuit court may take necessary administrative actions for this Act and its amendments, ceasing to exist for administrative purposes after 2 years. SEC. 15. EFFECTIVE DATE. SEC. 15. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect on the first day of the first fiscal year that begins at least 9 months after 5 judges authorized under section 4 are confirmed by the Senate. SEC. 16. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for implementing this Act, including funds for court facilities, are authorized to be appropriated.
